intro: Cruciata taurica subsp. mesopotamica, commonly known as the Mesopotamian cruciata, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the steppes of southern Russia and northern Iraq. It typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with erect, branching stems covered in fine hairs. The plant produces small, white to pale yellow flowers arranged in racemes, which bloom in the summer months. Its leaves are narrow and linear, often with a slight curl at the edges. This subspecies is adapted to dry, sandy soils and is often found in open habitats such as grasslands and along riverbanks.
